channel.title: Ubuntu App Path (user.dir fails)
channel.description: Hey, I'm new into Java so I was doing some stuff with basic file io, and in windows it worked just fine, but when I tried it in Ubuntu, the application path (which I got by using System.getProperty("user.dir")) returned home\user instead of giving the real jar path. I read one could use a function which returned the path of a resource, but my text file is only created if it doesn't exist, so It didn't help. Is there a way of getting the directory of the jar?

item.title: Ubuntu App Path (user.dir fails)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

As in:

File yourFile = new File("./yourFileName");

or

FileInputStream yourFileInputStream = new FileInputStream("./yourFileName");

etc etc, just use ‘.’ in the file name, and know it means the current working directory.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu App Path (user.dir fails)
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

… no, as in just use “.” as the directory.

. means current working directory in most operating systems. … means one level up.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu App Path (user.dir fails)
item.dc:creator: @ShKz ShKz
item.description:
@ShKz wrote:

Im looking for the working directory, so you say that placing a “.” in…? System.getProperty(".") ??

Thanks for the reply!

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu App Path (user.dir fails)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Are you trying to get the current working directory? If so, a simple “.” works in all operating systems. I’m not quite sure whether you are trying to get a file out of a jar, or a file in the same directory as a jar though, they are two different questions with different answers.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu App Path (user.dir fails)
item.dc:creator: @ShKz ShKz
item.description:
@ShKz wrote:

Hey,
I’m new into Java so I was doing some stuff with basic file io, and in windows it worked just fine, but when I tried it in Ubuntu, the application path (which I got by using System.getProperty(“user.dir”)) returned home\user instead of giving the real jar path. I read one could use a function which returned the path of a resource, but my text file is only created if it doesn’t exist, so It didn’t help. Is there a way of getting the directory of the jar?

Read full topic
